review_text: Beth Heim Jewish cemetery is very impressively maintained and presented for visitors to the site. There is no charge to enter. If you have an interest in Dutch / Jewish history then it's well worth visiting. Upon entry to Beth Haim, you can go inside a small round building on your left, where a very informative short film will play that explains the historical significance of the site and the work being done to preserve it. Some graves date back to the early 17th century, whilst there are some graves representing Jewish fatalities at Auschwitz in WW2.

Covering almost ten acres and established in 1614, Beth Haim is the oldest Jewish cemetery in the Netherlands. It's significance is such that it inspired works by the famous Dutch landscape painter Jacob van Ruisdael (1628 - 1682). In 1923 due to the burden of almost 28,000 graves on capacity, part of the cemetery was earthen covered to create more interment space. Heavy losses during World War Two further exacerbated the situation. A small but elegantly designed information visitors centre and map sculpture of the site is now in place. Today on wandering around this place of sublime peace with it's occasional trees and hedges, one is struck by the history, variety and elaborate artistic beauty of its tombstones.

While many gravestones have been buried in the swampy Dutch soil, lost in overgrown foliage or damaged, those that remain are quite extraordinary. They show inscriptions in Portuguese, Dutch, Latin and Hebrew, and feature loud, eccentric Baroque carvings that resemble Catholic headstones more than Jewish ones. The Baroque style of art and decoration is characterised by flamboyant detail, sharp contrasts, and bold, grand and surprising statement pieces intended to shock and/ or amuse. These visually energetic memorials give a vibrant nod to the lives of those interred and the era that they lived through.

Meandering through the graves is a morbidly fun excursion for any time of year, but seeing the gravestones partially flooded on a rainy day adds to the gloomy, sepulchral vibe.

- Contribution from Morbid Musings, South Africa
